intro: Macrorhynchus australis, commonly known as the southern giant lichen, is a unique and rare species of lichen found primarily in the southern regions of Australia. It is a composite organism consisting of a fungal partner and a photosynthetic alga, forming a symbiotic relationship that allows it to thrive in harsh environments. The plant exhibits a crustose growth form, adhering tightly to rock surfaces and often forming intricate patterns. It is particularly adapted to arid and semi-arid climates, where it plays a role in soil stabilization and nutrient cycling. Due to its limited distribution and sensitivity to environmental changes, it is considered a species of conservation concern.
